text: This knowledge base provides standardized, rule-driven maintenance actions for industrial assets based on pre-evaluated system rules. It is intended for retrieval-only maintenance agents that do not infer, reason, or override system decisions. All rule evaluation and confidence computation occur upstream.
Assets covered include industrial pumps, conveyor systems, and industrial compressors. Out of scope items include emergency shutdown procedures, design-level failures, and operator safety incidents.

Each maintenance rule maps to a specific condition, a deterministic action set, and a clear urgency level. Urgency levels are defined as Low (observe and monitor), Medium (inspect and plan), High (schedule corrective action), and Critical (immediate intervention required).

Condition: Excessive vibration levels during pump operation indicating bearing wear, shaft misalignment, or mechanical imbalance. Actions: Inspect pump bearings for wear or damage; verify shaft alignment and coupling condition; check foundation bolts and mounting rigidity; reduce operating load if possible; schedule corrective maintenance immediately. Continued operation is allowed only with close monitoring. Do not escalate immediately if the event is a single short-duration spike, if bearings were recently replaced, or if sensor mounting instability is detected.

Condition: Rapid temperature increase indicating lubrication flow issues, cooling inefficiency, or friction buildup. Actions: Inspect lubrication supply and quality; verify cooling water or airflow availability; check for blockages or restricted flow paths; monitor temperature trend over the next operational cycles.

Condition: Sustained pump temperature exceeding safe operating limits, indicating severe lubrication failure, internal friction, or imminent component damage. Actions: Reduce pump load immediately; inspect internal components; verify lubrication system integrity; prepare for controlled shutdown if elevated temperature persists.

Condition: Consistently high operating load indicating flow restriction, downstream blockage, or incorrect operating point. Actions: Inspect discharge and suction lines; check for valve restrictions; verify operating parameters against design specifications; monitor load trend over time.

Condition: Gradual increase in conveyor vibration indicating roller wear, belt misalignment, or structural looseness. Actions: Inspect conveyor rollers and bearings; verify belt alignment and tension; tighten structural fasteners; continue monitoring vibration trend.

Condition: Elevated conveyor motor temperature indicating overload conditions, cooling obstruction, or motor insulation stress. Actions: Inspect motor cooling system; verify load conditions; check ventilation pathways; monitor temperature stability.

Condition: High load peaks indicating material accumulation, belt slippage, or increased mechanical resistance. Actions: Inspect conveyor for material buildup; check belt tension and condition; verify motor and gearbox coupling; reduce throughput temporarily if required.

Condition: Sudden vibration spikes indicating foreign object intrusion, belt impact events, or roller seizure. Actions: Inspect conveyor path immediately; remove obstructions if present; inspect rollers for seizure; resume operation only after clearance.

Condition: Elevated compressor discharge temperature indicating compression inefficiency, cooling degradation, or valve leakage. Actions: Inspect cooling system; verify discharge pressure conditions; inspect compressor valves; monitor temperature trend.

Condition: High vibration instability indicating bearing damage, rotor imbalance, or internal mechanical faults. Actions: Inspect bearings and rotor alignment; verify foundation stability; reduce operating speed if possible; schedule corrective maintenance.

Condition: Rapid compressor temperature rise indicating lubrication failure, friction escalation, or abnormal compression behavior. Actions: Verify lubrication flow immediately; inspect cooling effectiveness; reduce load and monitor closely.

Condition: Sustained compressor overload indicating excessive demand, downstream restriction, or control system mismatch. Actions: Inspect discharge line restrictions; verify control settings; reduce operating load; schedule system inspection.

If conflicting or abnormal sensor readings occur, validate sensor calibration, check sensor mounting integrity, cross-verify readings with secondary sensors, and do not escalate mechanical maintenance prematurely.
Before inspection or maintenance activities, isolate the power supply, follow lock-out and tag-out procedures, wear appropriate personal protective equipment, and do not bypass safety interlocks.
This knowledge base provides advisory guidance only. Final maintenance decisions rest with qualified engineers. Site-specific operating conditions may require deviation from documented actions.
This knowledge base ensures deterministic maintenance actions, zero hallucination, and audit-ready operational guidance. It supports execution and retrieval, not decision-making.
